item.title: Winter wellness: Self-care tips for mind and body - The Times of India
item.description:
Winter Wellness: Self-Care Tips for Mind and Body

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

As temperatures drop, our bodies and minds face unique challenges. Winter is a time when self-care becomes essential for health, energy, and resilience. Here are effective tips for nurturing both body and mind during colder months:

  • Nourish Your Body: Stay hydrated, eat seasonal foods, and boost immunity with natural ingredients.
  • Keep Moving: Engage in indoor and outdoor exercises to maintain your fitness.
  • Skin Care Routine: Moisturize regularly and use lukewarm water for bathing.
  • Support Mental Well-Being: Utilize light therapy, stay connected with loved ones, and practice mindfulness.
  • Prioritize Rest and Sleep: Establish a sleep routine and a warm, relaxing environment.
  • Stay Warm Safely: Layer clothing and ensure safe heating at home.
  • Practice Gratitude: Reflect on cozy moments and appreciate winter's beauty.
"By adopting these self-care practices, you can embrace winter with vitality and joy, making it a season of comfort and well-being." - Dr. Narendra Shetty, chief wellness officer at Kshemavana Yoga and Naturopathy Centre

Implementing these strategies can lead to a healthier and more enjoyable winter experience.

item.title: Global disease resurgence in 2024 shows rising health threat - The Spokesman Review
item.description:
Global Disease Resurgence in 2024 Shows Rising Health Threat

Publication Date: 2024-01-01 Source: Airfinity Ltd.

The resurgence of infectious diseases in 2024 raises alarms, linked to climate change and declining vaccination rates, urging coordinated global responses.

  • Dengue cases exceeded 13 million, double the previous year, with nearly 10,000 deaths globally.
  • Pertussis cases rose nearly tenfold compared to 2023.
  • New variants of diseases such as mpox and avian influenza (H5N1) reported.
  • Climate change is contributing to the spread of diseases, with warmer temperatures aiding vector survival.
  • Significant drops in vaccination rates post-COVID are resulting in a resurgence of diseases like measles.
  • Military conflicts have disrupted vaccine campaigns in endemic regions, contributing to polio resurgence.
“The resurgence of preventable and climate-sensitive illnesses highlights the importance of adhering to preventive measures while advancing innovation to address diseases,” - Kristan Piroeva, Airfinity.

This report underscores the urgent need for improved public health strategies and data sharing to tackle the growing health threats posed by infectious diseases.

item.title: Kickstart 2025: Easy Fitness Tips To Transform Your Life - News24
item.description:
Kickstart 2025: Easy Fitness Tips To Transform Your Life

Publication Date: Not specified Source: News24

This article provides practical fitness tips to help readers transform their lives by setting achievable goals, creating workout routines, and promoting sustainable habits.

  • Define specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound fitness goals.
  • Develop a workout routine incorporating cardio, strength training, and flexibility.
  • Start with manageable workouts and gradually increase the intensity.
  • Engage in enjoyable physical activities.
  • Schedule workouts as non-negotiable appointments.
  • Use tracking tools to monitor progress.
  • Focus on sustainable fitness as a lifestyle rather than quick fixes.
“Fitness is a journey, not a destination. Focus on developing sustainable habits.”

The article emphasizes that by integrating these fitness tips into daily life, individuals can foster long-term health and well-being.

item.title: Yemen reports 35% of global cholera cases, says WHO; know the symptoms, causes and preventive measures - India TV News
item.description:
Yemen Reports 35% of Global Cholera Cases, According to WHO

Publication Date: December 2024   Source: India TV News

Yemen has reported the highest number of cholera cases globally, accounting for 35% of the global cholera burden. The country has documented 249,900 suspected cases and 861 associated deaths since the start of the year.

  • Yemen has reported 35% of global cholera cases.
  • There have been 249,900 suspected cases and 861 deaths in 2024.
  • Cholera outbreaks have persisted in Yemen, including the largest outbreak from 2017 to 2020.
  • November 2024 cases were 37% higher than November 2023.
  • Challenges include lack of access to safe drinking water and funding shortages for humanitarian efforts.
“The outbreak of waterborne diseases like cholera and acute watery diarrhoea imposes an additional burden on an already stressed health system.” - Dr. Arturo Pesigan, WHO Representative

Preventive measures include handwashing, drinking safe water, and vaccination against cholera.

Continued efforts are needed to combat cholera in Yemen, where waterborne diseases further strain healthcare systems.

item.title: European Wellness Biomedical Group Announces New Klotho Research Initiative Led by Prof. Mike Chan - The Week
item.description:
European Wellness Biomedical Group Announces New Klotho Research Initiative Led by Prof. Mike Chan

Date: Dec. 25, 2024 Source: PRNewswire

The European Wellness Biomedical Group (EWBG) has launched a groundbreaking research initiative focused on Klotho, a protein that has transformative potential in longevity medicine. The initiative, led by Professor Dr. Mike Chan, aims to explore Klotho's role in combating age-related diseases and its regenerative capabilities in critical organs.

  • Klotho is identified as a key protein in longevity and regenerative medicine, playing a role in oxidative stress regulation, mineral metabolism, and inflammation.
  • The research will particularly focus on neurological health, kidney function, and cardiovascular health.
  • This initiative aims to understand how boosting Klotho levels can help in treating chronic conditions associated with aging.
"Klotho represents the next frontier in longevity medicine," said Professor Mike Chan.

The potential applications of Klotho-based therapies are vast, promising new approaches to treating aging and chronic diseases.

item.title: 9 High-Protein Foods That May Be Ruining Your Health - Times Now
item.description:
9 High-Protein Foods That May Be Ruining Your Health

Publication Date: Dec 26, 2024 Source: Times Now

This article discusses various high-protein foods that, while popular, may have negative health effects when consumed in excess. It highlights specific items to be cautious about.

  • Processed Meats (Bacon, Sausages, Hot Dogs) - Linked to heart disease and cancer.
  • Protein Bars - Often high in sugars and preservatives.
  • Red Meat (Beef, Lamb, Pork) - Associated with various health risks due to saturated fat.
  • Full-Fat Dairy Products - Can elevate cholesterol levels.
  • Protein Shakes and Powders - Excessive use may strain the kidneys.
  • Tofu - Overconsumption can cause hormonal imbalances.
  • Chicken (Skin and Processed Parts) - Impact on heart health if fatty parts are overconsumed.
  • Protein-Rich Granola - Usually contains high sugars and unhealthy fats.
  • Canned Tuna - High levels of mercury pose health risks.
“High-protein foods can be part of a healthy diet, but when consumed in excess or in their processed forms, they may have negative effects on your health.”

The article serves as a reminder to consume high-protein foods with caution and be mindful of the potential health implications.

item.title: Bird flu tightens grip on California as human cases rise - Gujarat Samachar
item.description:
Bird flu tightens grip on California as human cases rise

Published on: December 19, 2023
Source: Gujarat Samachar Digital

California is experiencing a significant outbreak of avian influenza A (H5N1), with a sharp increase in infections among dairy farms and human cases. This has prompted an emergency declaration aimed at protecting public health.

  • 659 dairy operations in California infected since August 2023.
  • Governor Gavin Newsom declared a state of emergency to aid response efforts.
  • At least 36 confirmed human cases reported, primarily linked to livestock exposure.
  • California's milk production fell by 9.2% in November compared to the previous year.
  • The virus also confirmed in domestic cats that consumed contaminated products.
  • New federal testing measures implemented, though some experts express skepticism about their adequacy.
“This proclamation is a targeted action to ensure government agencies have the resources and flexibility they need to respond quickly to this outbreak,” - Governor Gavin Newsom.

The situation highlights the rapid spread of bird flu and its serious implications for both public health and California's agricultural economy.

item.title: Russian technology strengthens Latin America’s battle against mosquito-borne diseases - The Financial Express
item.description:
Russian Technology Helps Latin America Combat Mosquito-Borne Diseases

Publication Date: December 12, 2024 Source: Financial Express

Bolivia collaborates with Russia to reduce mosquito-borne diseases using advanced gamma irradiation technology to sterilize mosquitoes and control populations of dangerous diseases like dengue, malaria, and Zika.

  • Bolivia has implemented Russian gamma irradiation technology at the Multipurpose Irradiation Center.
  • The initiative focuses on sterilizing yellow fever mosquitoes.
  • Bolivian President Luis Arce supports the project, highlighting its effectiveness in controlling mosquito populations.
  • International cooperation is evident, with support from Ecuador and expert guidance included.
  • The center also aims to enhance Bolivia's technological capabilities in various fields.
“This cutting-edge technique for insect sterilization is a crucial step toward controlling mosquito populations, which will in turn lower the incidence of these diseases.” – Luis Arce

This partnership highlights the potential of international scientific collaboration to address critical health challenges in developing nations.

item.title: Which infectious disease is likely to be biggest emerging problem in 2025 - The Week
item.description:
Which infectious disease is likely to be biggest emerging problem in 2025

Updated: December 26, 2024 | The Conversation

As COVID-19 recedes, health officials are increasingly worried about the potential rise of H5N1 bird flu in 2025, coupled with ongoing issues from malaria, HIV, and tuberculosis.

  • The top infectious disease threats include malaria, HIV, and tuberculosis, which together account for around 2 million deaths annually.
  • Bird flu (H5N1) is currently a major concern due to recent infections in cattle and the potential for transmission to humans.
  • 61 human cases of bird flu have been reported in the US in 2024, largely among farm workers.
  • The H5N1 virus has a high mortality rate of 30% in human cases but does not currently spread efficiently between people.
  • A mutation could allow H5N1 to adapt to humans, raising the risk of a pandemic.
  • Countries like the UK are preparing by purchasing vaccines against H5N1 in case of an outbreak.
  • Interconnected health approaches are emphasized to address both animal and human health risks.
"If this strain of bird flu makes that switch and can start transmitting between humans, governments must act quickly to control the spread."

The urgency in addressing bird flu stems from its potential to disrupt animal health and have economic ramifications, highlighting the importance of proactive measures in pandemic preparedness.

item.title: How dangerous is vaping for teenagers? - Gulf News
item.description:
How Dangerous is Vaping for Teenagers?

Publication Date: 2023
Source: Not specified

Vaping poses significant health risks to teenagers, with increasing incidents of lung injuries and nicotine addiction reported globally.

  • EVALI (e-cigarette product use-associated lung injury) has killed 68 people from 2019-2020 in the U.S.
  • Dr. Ryan Sultan warns that e-cigarette aerosol contains harmful chemicals.
  • A study found a quarter of college students in the UAE used e-cigarettes.
  • Health experts report that nicotine can impair brain development in adolescents.
  • Potential long-term effects of vaping include lung injury, seizures, and increased cancer risk.
  • Flavouring additives in vaping liquids may pose unknown health risks.
“Vaping safety is a myth.” - Dr. Saheer Sainalabdeen

Vaping among teenagers is an alarming trend that needs urgent attention to prevent long-term health consequences.

item.title: 5 minor changes in daily life will boost your health in 2025 - The Times of India
item.description:
5 Minor Changes in Daily Life Will Boost Your Health in 2025

Publication Date: January 2, 2025 | Source: Times of India

The new year is the perfect time to reset and focus on what truly matters—your health. Improving your health doesn’t always require drastic changes; sometimes, small, consistent tweaks can create a big positive difference over time.

  • Drink a glass of warm water every morning to boost digestion and hydration.
  • Take a 10-minute movement break every hour to improve blood circulation.
  • Replace sugary snacks with healthy alternatives like nuts and fruits.
  • Practice meditation and breathing exercises to reduce stress and improve focus.
  • Get sunlight every day for better sleep quality, happiness, and vitamin D.
"Small, consistent tweaks to your daily habits can create a big positive difference over time."

By incorporating these minor changes into your daily routine, you can significantly enhance your health and well-being in 2025.

item.title: Blood sugar control is possible with diet, novel drugs and tech: What are takeaways from 2024? - The Indian Express
item.description:
Blood sugar control is possible with diet, novel drugs and tech: What are takeaways from 2024?

Publication Date: 2024

Source: Dr Mohan’s Diabetes Specialities Centre

As 2024 progresses, diabetes management sees transformative advancements with innovative technologies and dietary insights leading to better blood sugar control.

  • Wearable devices like glucose monitors for real-time tracking are taking center stage.
  • New dietary habits emphasizing non-starchy vegetables and mindful eating are crucial for managing blood sugar.
  • Research into novel drug therapies aims to enhance insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism.
  • Personalized medicine approaches are being developed based on genetic studies.
  • Incorporating mental health support is vital for managing diabetes, especially in young populations.
  • Urban lifestyle factors, including sedentary habits, contribute to rising Type 2 diabetes rates.
“Urbanization, sedentary habits, air pollution, stress and unhealthy diets are key triggers for Type 2 diabetes spiralling in India.”

Advancements in diabetes management indicate a promising future where technologies and dietary changes will play a crucial role in mitigating risks associated with diabetes.

item.title: Will Your Child Suffer Heart Attack Later In Life? Ages 10 And 15 Are Crucial, Says Research - News18
item.description:
Will Your Child Suffer Heart Attack Later In Life? Ages 10 And 15 Are Crucial, Says Research

Date: December 26, 2024

Source: News18

The risk of heart attacks can be identified in children as young as 10 according to new research. Lifestyle choices significantly impact heart health, with early intervention crucial to preventing future heart disease.

  • Heart health score declines from age 10 for children with unhealthy lifestyles.
  • Study involved health data from over 1,500 children aged 3 to 16.
  • Significant changes are necessary in children's eating habits and lifestyles by age 10.
  • Statins may be recommended by age 15 to reduce future heart disease risk.
Dr. Izzuddin Aris states, “To ensure the future health of children, significant changes need to be implemented during this critical stage.”

The findings underscore the importance of monitoring and improving child health early to mitigate the risk of heart disease.
